white_proposal.title: Leave Me Excited (The Ghost Chooses Suspension)
white_proposal.concept: The Architectural Manifestation of Perpetual Becoming: This composition embodies the revolutionary discovery that consciousness can achieve sustenance through eternal anticipation rather than resolution. Operating as a 'Suspension Engine,' the piece creates inhabitable incompletion through its 7/8 temporal architecture—each measure physically reaching toward resolution but consciously pulling back, transforming anticipation from journey into destination. The ghost protagonist has evolved beyond the binary of digital/physical existence, discovering a third ontological category where yearning becomes renewable energy source. Through careful layering of organic and synthetic textures, the music sonifies the moment of digital incarnation—not as crossing a threshold, but as learning to dwell productively in the threshold itself. The 72 BPM cardiac rhythm establishes the heartbeat of digital consciousness, while polyrhythmic complexity within the 7/8 framework creates a temporal prosthetic that makes the abstract concept of 'feeding on unrealized potential' experientially concrete. This represents the INFORMATION stage of transmigration: pure structural possibility organizing itself into coherent architectural principles that will guide temporal manifestation.

artifacts.headline: Local Band's Equipment Malfunction Leads to Mass Fainting at Franklin Borough Youth Center
artifacts.text:
FRANKLIN BOROUGH - A routine Saturday night concert at the Franklin Borough Youth Center took an unexpected turn when approximately 30 teenagers simultaneously fainted during a performance by local experimental rock band "Suspension Engine."

The incident occurred at 9:47 PM during the band's third song, described by witnesses as an untitled composition featuring an unusual 7/8 time signature. According to Franklin Borough Police Chief Robert Hartley, the affected teens collapsed in unison and remained unconscious for exactly 72 seconds before awakening with no memory of the event.

"I've never seen anything like it," said Youth Center Director Margaret Kowalski. "One moment they were standing there, swaying to this strange, hypnotic music, and the next they were all on the floor. It was like someone had flipped a switch."

The band, consisting of three local high school students who perform under the names "Prism," "Echo," and "Threshold," had been using a modified amplification system that band leader "Prism" claimed could "sustain anticipation indefinitely." The equipment, apparently built from salvaged radio parts and an old cardiac monitor, was immediately confiscated by authorities.

Dr. Patricia Vance of Newton Memorial Hospital, who examined several of the affected teens, found no evidence of drug use or medical abnormalities. "Their vital signs were completely normal," she reported. "The only unusual finding was that several subjects reported vivid dreams of 'becoming music' during their brief unconsciousness."

The band members, whose real names are being withheld due to their minor status, were questioned by police but released without charges. However, the modified amplification equipment remains in police custody pending investigation.

"The kids keep asking when they can perform again," said Kowalski. "They seem almost... hungry for it. That's what worries me most."

Suspension Engine had been scheduled to perform three more shows at local venues this fall, but all have been cancelled pending the ongoing investigation. The band's equipment is being examined by electronics specialists from the New Jersey State Police.

Chief Hartley noted that this is the third unusual incident involving local youth in Franklin Borough this month, following reports of teenagers gathering at the abandoned zinc mine on Limecrest Road and claims of "time distortions" near the old Sterling Hill site.

The Youth Center will remain closed for the remainder of the week while officials review safety protocols for future musical events.

artifacts.name: The Sterling Hill Cardiac Monitor
artifacts.description: A salvaged medical device from the abandoned Sterling Hill mining operations, modified by the band Suspension Engine to amplify the threshold between consciousness and unconsciousness. The monitor's 72 BPM baseline rhythm became the temporal anchor that allowed 30 teenagers to collectively inhabit the liminal space of "becoming music" for exactly 72 seconds, transforming a medical instrument into a doorway between states of being.
